caption_text: As shown in Fig. 1, in the virgin solid zone, the temperature is not high enough for thermal decomposition reactions. In the reaction zone, both chemical composition and phys- ical structural changes occur. First, the high molecu- lar organic materials decompose into small radical fragments which include gases (about 5%) and liquids (approximately 60%).
raw_window: As shown in Fig. 1, in the virgin solid zone, the temperature is not high enough for thermal decomposition reactions.
In the reaction zone, both chemical composition and phys- ical structural changes occur.
First, the high molecu- lar organic materials decompose into small radical fragments which include gases (about 5%) and liquids (approximately 60%).

caption_text: In the reacted zone, as most of the volatiles have left, the porous solid structure allows an easy flow of the volatile vapors from the reaction zone towards the Carbon Black Reaction Zone ~--~ Virgin Tire ~~ ~(~= Qr I ~ Reaction Heat Transfer Mass Transfer Fig. 1. caption_text: Three steps can be identi- fied in Fig. 2. When the temperature rises from room temperature to less than 180°C, the temperature is not high enough for the reactions to become significant and thus no important weight loss or enthalpy change is observed. When the temperature rises from 180 to 400°C, the continuous input of energy triggers signifi- cant tire pyrolysis reactions.
raw_window: Three steps can be identi- fied in Fig. 2.

When the temperature rises from room temperature to less than 180°C, the temperature is not high enough for the reactions to become significant and thus no important weight loss or enthalpy change is observed.
When the temperature rises from 180 to 400°C, the continuous input of energy triggers signifi- cant tire pyrolysis reactions.

caption_text: The exothermic enthalpy change in Fig. 2 may re- sult from complex chemical reactions, such as thermal decomposition, cyclization, crosslinking, repolymeriz- ation, etc. (Lehrle, 1987). An equation to describe the heat release process was developed by Yang and Roy (1995), based on the simulations of the DTA and DSC enthalpy measurements, and is expressed as -- dCi qd = ~hd,"~ (3) where h~ is the reaction heat, dC/dt the rate of elas- tomer decomposition and i the elastomer component.

caption_text: Simulation of the measured temperature history The experimental measured temperature history at the centre of the particle is illustrated in Fig. 4 (curve 1). First, for the preheating period between 0 and 115min, a slow linear temperature increase from room temperature to 130°C is observed. No pyrolysis reaction happens during this period.
raw_window: Simulation of the measured temperature history The experimental measured temperature history at the centre of the particle is illustrated in Fig. 4 (curve 1).
First, for the preheating period between 0 and 115min, a slow linear temperature increase from room temperature to 130°C is observed.
No pyrolysis reaction happens during this period.

caption_text: In Fig. 4, a corresponding temperature in- crease is observed at t = 122 rain, and the delay of 7min is due to intraparticle heat transfer. At t = 127 min, when the tire temperature reaches 305°C, exothermic pyrolysis reactions contribute to a further rise of the particle temperature. An exothermic peak at TMAX = 445°C is observed in Fig. 4.
raw_window: In Fig. 4, a corresponding temperature in- crease is observed at t = 122 rain, and the delay of 7min is due to intraparticle heat transfer.
At t = 127 min, when the tire temperature reaches 305°C, exothermic pyrolysis reactions contribute to a further rise of the particle temperature.
An exothermic peak at TMAX = 445°C is observed in Fig. 4.

caption_text: Simulation of the experimental measured temper- ature history was carried out with different values of me, and the best experimental fit was obtained when mc was set at 80% of the VM content, or 0.8VM (Fig. 4, curve 3). During the numerical simulation, it was noted that the temperature history before pyroly- sis reactions depends mainly on the values of the specific heat capacity Ce and the thermal conductivity 2. The value of the kinetic parameters has an impor- tant effect on the location of the exothermic peak during the pyrolysis reactions.
raw_window: Simulation of the experimental measured temper- ature history was carried out with different values of me, and the best experimental fit was obtained when mc was set at 80% of the VM content, or 0.8VM (Fig. 4, curve 3).
During the numerical simulation, it was noted that the temperature history before pyroly- sis reactions depends mainly on the values of the specific heat capacity Ce and the thermal conductivity 2.
The value of the kinetic parameters has an impor- tant effect on the location of the exothermic peak during the pyrolysis reactions.

caption_text: The simulated temperature histories with mc = 0.0 VM (curve 2), 0.8 VM (curve 3) and 1.0 VM (curve 4) are compared in Fig. 4. When mc is 0.0 VM (curve 2), there is no vapor accumulation and the volatiles leave the matrix as soon as they are produced. Thus after the exothermic pyrolysis reac- tions, no flat period is observed.
raw_window: The simulated temperature histories with mc = 0.0 VM (curve 2), 0.8 VM (curve 3) and 1.0 VM (curve 4) are compared in Fig. 4.
When mc is 0.0 VM (curve 2), there is no vapor accumulation and the volatiles leave the matrix as soon as they are produced.
Thus after the exothermic pyrolysis reac- tions, no flat period is observed.

caption_text: A sharp endothermic peak occurs, which is very similar to that on the DTA curve in Fig. 3 where the mass transfer resistance is negligible. In this limit case, the model becomes more or less similar to the "shrinking core" or "moving boundary" models which assumes that the reaction zone is very thin and that the vapors can leave the particle surface right after they are produced. When mc is 1.0 VM, the vapor bubbles break only when all of the liquid is evaporated; thus a very long flat period is observed.
raw_window: A sharp endothermic peak occurs, which is very similar to that on the DTA curve in Fig. 3 where the mass transfer resistance is negligible.

When mc is 1.0 VM, the vapor bubbles break only when all of the liquid is evaporated; thus a very long flat period is observed.

caption_text: 1917 Fig. 6. They illustrate the propagation of heat and pyrolysis from the surface towards the center along the radial direction. caption_text: However, these stages are less obvious compared with the temperature curves in Fig. 5. This is due to a shorter distance and a stronger heat flux in the radial direction, which make the temperature curves more influenced by the external heat transfer. 9.2.

caption_text: It is followed by a constant mass period, which corres- ponds to the flat temperature period in Fig. 4. A major mass loss occurs in the third stage, in the temperature range of 420-480°C, in which all the residual liquids are evaporated. The solid lines correspond to the total mass change during the pyrolysis, including the solid carbon black, the liquids and the accumulated vapors.

caption_text: In Fig. 10, a very sharp heat release is observed at time 139 min for the pyrolysis reactions. This phenomenon lasts only 2 min, during which about 308 kJkg-l heat is released. Consequently, a very sharp temperature rise is observed.

caption_text: The heat of evaporation in Fig. 11 is proportional to the rate of VM evaporation. Three peaks of heat consumption can be observed on the evaporation curve in Fig. 11, as a result of the three-stage volatile evaporation in Fig. 7 (the dashed lines). The total heat of evaporation for the truck tire particle sample tested is 181 kJ kg- 1.

caption_text: Table 1 gives characteristic times for the physical and chem- ical processes during the pyrolysis of a tire particle, including heat conduction, pyrolysis reactions, vol- atiles transportation in the reaction zone (including diffusion and bubble transportation phenomena) and viscous flow in the reacted zone (flow of volatile vapors across the porous carbon black towards the surface of the particle).
raw_window: Table 1 gives characteristic times for the physical and chem- ical processes during the pyrolysis of a tire particle, including heat conduction, pyrolysis reactions, vol- atiles transportation in the reaction zone (including diffusion and bubble transportation phenomena) and viscous flow in the reacted zone (flow of volatile vapors across the porous carbon black towards the surface of the particle).
The thermal and kinetic para- meters used in the study are presented in Table 2.
The permeability B is estimated according to the radius of micro-pores inside of carbon black which is about 1 I.tm (Hess et al., 1967).

caption_text: Table 1 also shows that the intra- particle heat transfer is faster than the transportation of pyrolysis products. An accumulation of pyrolysis products is therefore produced inside of the particle, resulting in a wide zone of vapor bubbles.
raw_window: Table 1 also shows that the intra- particle heat transfer is faster than the transportation of pyrolysis products.
An accumulation of pyrolysis products is therefore produced inside of the particle, resulting in a wide zone of vapor bubbles.
Among the two mass transfer phenomena, the rate of viscous flow in the carbon black zone is several orders of magni- tude higher than the "bubble" mass transfer.
table_reason: The caption ends after S1, as S2 introduces new technical details beyond the scope of a standard table caption.
